title: Module 1: Introduction to omics technologies
text:
Summary



The field of omic data analysis has been rapidly evolving during the last two decades. Moreover, the importance of bioinformatics in biomedical research has steadily continued to increase, becoming an almost a required skill for any researcher in the field. Throughout this module, the students will: - Obtain a comprehensive overview of the available omics. - Learn which omic may be more suitable for a given research question. - Learn how to analyze several types of omics.

title: Module 1: Introduction to omics technologies
text:
Morning lecture
We will start the lecture with a brief historical review of the omics field. Commonly used omic technologies, such as genomics, epigenetics, transcriptomics, proteomics and metabolomics, will be presented throughtout the lecture. We will also talk about the present trends of omics technologies and possible future developments. In particular, we will mention recent advances such as single-cell (2012) and spatial omics (2022) data.

title: Module 1: Introduction to omics technologies
text:
Afternoon workshop
In this first workshop we will present bioinformatic pipelines for the analysis of some common omics. We will mainly focus on the initial processing and quality control (downstream analysis will be covered in the following modules). While some of same principles can found in the analysis of multiple omics, some omics require special software/packages; our aim with this workshop is to teach which tools should be used depending on the omic. We will provide basic pipelines for the analysis of different omic data, such as whole-genome sequencing, single-cell RNA-seq and Olink proteomics.

title: Module 1: Introduction to omics technologies
text:
Lectures and Materials
A markdown tutorial will be uploaded before the workshop.

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Course description
This PhD course provides an interdisciplinary exploration of omics technologies, AI and data-driven precision health, merging theories with hands-on practice. Ideal for students interested in the intersection of AI, bioinformatics, and personalized medicine, the course delves into AI and machine learning techniques for analyzing multi-omics data, enhancing disease diagnosis, and optimizing treatment strategies. Ethical, legal, and social considerations of AI in healthcare are also examined to ensure responsible use of these technologies.

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Learning Outcomes

Knowledge and understanding

Describe the principles of AI as applied to precision medicine, and identify the healthcare challenges these technologies aim to address.
Describe the roles of AI technologies in analyzing biomedical data for disease diagnosis, treatment optimization, and the development of personalized healthcare solutions.
Understand the differentiate between the capabilities and limitations of various AI and ML approaches in the context of precision medicine, including supervised and unsupervised learning, neural networks, and deep learning.
Describe the significance of multi-omics data analysis in precision medicine and how AI technologies facilitate the interpretation of complex biological information.
Discuss the ethical, legal, and social implications of employing AI in healthcare, focusing on privacy, data security, and equitable access to medical innovations.



Competence and skills

Apply state-of-the-art methods to integrate multi-omics data.
Apply AI and ML approaches to address precision medicine problems.
Analyze and interpret biomedical data using AI-driven methods.
Apply AI technologies to propose solutions to current problems in precision medicine.



Judgement and approach

Demonstrate a critical approach to the selection and application of AI and ML methods in biomedical research, ensuring the reliability and validity of findings.

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Target audience and course prerequisites
Target audience: PhD students with ongoing or planned projects involving omics data analysis
Course prerequisites: Second-cycle degree, Basic programming skills

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Forms of instruction and examination
Forms of instruction: In-person, digital communications
Forms of study: self-studies (incl. independent work), group activities, lectures, discussion seminars, and workshop Language: English
Examination: Active participation in all sessions and group assignments. The final examination is a group-based data analysis project with an oral presentation.

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Additional notes

Please install the programming tools (R, Python) before class and bring your computer to the workshop.

title: Hands-on project and data analysis
text: The students will be randomly divided into groups of approximately 4 people. For this project, the students will be given a synthetic multi-omics dataset; the objective is to perform data integration analyses and to present the results during an oral presentation (tentative date: 30rd October 2025).

title: Module 3: Principles of artificial intelligence, machine learning and network analysis
text:
Summary



A massive number of tools are available for bioinformatic analyses. In this module we will guide the students across the most important categories of analyses that can be performed. We will look at classical tools, e.g. linear regression, as well as more recent approaches, e.g. neural networks. After this module, the students will: - Have an overview of the different types of analyses that concern omic data. - Be able to perform these analyses on their data.

title: Module 3: Principles of artificial intelligence, machine learning and network analysis
text:
Morning lecture
The lecture will cover a broad spectrum of analyses that can be performed, such as: - High-dimensionality reduction techniques. - Clustering: supervised and unsupervised. - Regression - Reinforcement machine learning - Network analysis - Generative AI, transfer learning and explainable AI During this lecture, we will present what goals we can achieve with these tools, together with their limitations.

title: Module 3: Principles of artificial intelligence, machine learning and network analysis
text:
Afternoon workshop
During the workshop, we will present the main R/Python packages that can be used to perform the analyses discussed during the lectures. Examples with code will be provided.

title: Module 3: Principles of artificial intelligence, machine learning and network analysis
text:
Seminar
The students will be given a paper on the topic of the module to read, that will be discussed during the seminar. Active partcipation during the seminar is a requirement to pass.

title: Module 2: Omics integration
text:
Summary



Analyzing paired omics generated from the same biological samples promises to give a more holistic view of the biological processes. However, there remain several practical questions on how to integrate multi-omics effectively. In this module we will present what strategies are currently used by researchers for this purpose. After this module, the students will: - Know what are the advantages of multi-omics approaches. - Be able to implement state-of-the-art analyses for multi-omics integration.

title: Module 2: Omics integration
text:
Morning lecture
In the lecture we will discuss the advantages of multi-omics data; positive examples from the literature will be shown to highlight the potential benefits. We will present multiple strategies that have been successfully adopted by researchers to integrate multi-omics data. Pitfalls and open questions regarding multi-omics integration will also be discussed.

title: Module 2: Omics integration
text:
Afternoon workshop
In this workshop we will take a look at available tools for multi-omics integration as well as versatile analysis strategies that can be used for multiple multi-omics.

title: Module 2: Omics integration

title: Module 4: Translational omics and precision health
text:
Summary



In this module we will present some of the applications of translational omics research, with particular focus on precision health.

title: Module 4: Translational omics and precision health
text:
Morning lecture
The lecture will cover some of the applications of multi-omics analysis, drawing examples from the literature, such as: - Biomarker discovery. - Population health and precision health. - Drug discovery and development.

title: Teachers
text:
Wen Zhong []https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7422-6104)  

Assistant Professor, Linköping, Department of Biomedical and Clinical Sciences (BKV)





Wen Zhong mainly focuses on the integration of multi-omics, the interplay between genetics and phenotypes, and the development of data-driven strategies/tools for precision medicine. The aim is to investigate the molecular biomarkers for the estimation of disease risks, early diagnosis of disease, stratification of drug treatment response, disease progression monitoring and the stratification of patients.





Jing Wang   

Postdoctoral researcher, Linköping, Department of Biomedical and Clinical Sciences (BKV)
